presentation.title: Open space proximity
presentation.runninghead: Values resulting from open space proximity.
presentation.description: Aesthetic values are typically defined as the value derived from views or proximity to open space. These values often accrue to housing or property values and are often measured using hedonic pricing. Homeowners typically gain some combination of benefits through sensory enjoyment of views of nearby open space, proximity to open space for recreation, or privacy. This storyline maps ecosytem service provision, use, and flows for open space proximity, including the type and quality of open space, location and type of housing, the presence of highways that can block easy access to open space, and flow models to connect beneficiaries to open space via walking simulation.

page.name: Open space proximity
page.title: Introduction
page.description: This storyline considers the contribution of ecosystems toward providing high-quality open space, and the impact of open space on property values. The source model quantifies open space quality, the sink model maps highways that reduce privacy and obstruct direct access to open space, and the use model maps the location of homeowners. By combining these maps with a walking simulation model, we can analyze actual open space proximity its potential impact on property values.

page.name: Riparian or wetland presence and quality
page.title: Riparian or wetland presence and quality
page.runninghead: Riparian or wetland presence and quality.
page.description:
Presence of high, moderate, low quality, or no riparian or wetland habitat, a relatively high-value open space type for nearby residences.

Role in models

Riparian and wetland presence data are combined with data on riparian quality (where available) to further estimate the quality of the surface water resource. Given its rarity in the Southwest, riparian habitat has been found to contribute relatively high value to nearby property.

Representation

Data are categorical.

Source

Derived from SWREGAP land use-land cover data and riparian condition class data (Stromberg, J.C., et al. 2006. Status of the riparian ecosystem in the Upper San Pedro River, Arizona: Application of an assessment model. Environmental Monitoring and Assessment 115: 145-173.)

page.name: Potential proximity value
page.title: Potential proximity value
page.description:
The quality of potential open space for nearby residences.

Role in models

This is the output of the proximity source model, and estimates the relative quality of different areas in providing aesthetically valuable open space, based on relevant input data for the type of open space and its relative quality.

Representation

The data are in abstract units from 0-100, representing relative suitability of different parts of the landscape to provide aesthetically valuable open space. As the output of the models is probabilistic, each point contains the probability distribution for potential open space quality. The distribution can be visualized by clicking on the map; the mean value and the coefficient of variation are reported along with the probabilities.

Source

This map has been computed at your request by a Bayesian model built and calibrated by the ARIES server for the selected area.

page.name: Highways
page.title: Presence of highways
page.description:
The presence of highways, which limit immediate access to open space and reduce privacy.

Role in models

Highways are used as the sink layer for open space proximity. Although highways can increase access to parks and other open space, for the purposes of property value benefits from open space proximity, highways increase noise, reduce privacy, and restrict the ability to easily walk to the nearby open space parcel. They thus act as sinks in the proximity flow model.

Representation

Data are represented as a presence or absence map showing the location of highways.

Source

TIGER Line Files.

page.name: Urban proximity
page.title: Urban proximity
page.description:
Urban proximity, measured here based on population density, reflects both the scarcity of open space and the degree of crowding, which can increase demand for open space. In dense urban areas, open space is relatively more valuable, on a per-area basis, than in rural areas where open space is abundant.

Role in models

Housing locations, housing value, and population density data are used as inputs to a probabilistic model to estimate the potential aesthetic value, as reflected in property value, of open space proximity.

Representation

Data are in physical units of persons per square kilometer.

Source

U.S. Census Bureau population estimates and TIGER block group files.

page.name: Possible proximate open space
page.title: Possible proximate open space
page.description:
*Possible flow maps* represent the path that the carrier of the service would take if it was not intercepted by sinks. As such it considers source and use models and shows the maximum amount of flow. For provisioning services, this corresponds to the maximum potential benefit; for preventive services, the maximum potential damage.
This map shows the flow of proximity from natural areas toward homeowners, before accounting for highways that limit local access.
page.see-also: The aesthetic views and proximity section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Accessible open space
page.title: Accessible open space
page.description:
Even in the absence of sinks, not all of a source quantity actually has the ability to reach users, because of the route that an ecosystem service carrier moves across the landscape. Flow analysis allows us to identify which particular portion of the total source quantity is actually generating carriers that reach the users, independent of the existence of sinks but taking into account the result of use values, the structure of the landscape and the flow paths of the carrier, producing this *possible source map*. For provisioning services, this corresponds to the source of benefits that has the potential of being actually useful. For preventive services, this corresponds to the portion of the source field that could actually cause damage to people. The location and strength of sinks determines how much of the source actually reaches the users.
This map shows open space providing value when accounting for proximity and the location of homeowners but not highways that limit local access.
page.see-also: The aesthetic views and proximity section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Open space proximate homeowners
page.title: Open space proximate homeowners
page.description:
*Possible use maps* show the locations of users on the landscape that can receive a benefit due to flow connections with a source of an ecosystem service carrier, but may or may not actually receive the carrier due to the action of sinks. For provisioning services, potential use identifies areas where it is physically possible for a benefit to be received. For preventive services, potential use identifies areas that may be damaged by a detrimental carrier if sinks do not prevent such damage.
This map shows homeowners benefiting from proximity after accounting for sources of open space and their flow paths, but before accounting for highways that limit local access.
page.see-also: The aesthetic views and proximity section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Accessible proximity
page.title: Accessible proximity flow
page.description:
The *actual flow density* map shows the flow paths that deliver actual services to humans. These are selected from the total flow density to only show these flow paths that are not depleted by sinks and actually reach users.
For provisioning services, these flow paths deliver valuable benefits to the users and the density is proportional to the value accrued. For preventive services, the flow paths show how much of the carrier reaches users, delivering actual damage.
This map shows the actual flow of proximity from natural areas toward homeowners, when accounting for sinks and flow paths.
page.see-also: The aesthetic views and proximity section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Enjoyed open space
page.title: Enjoyed open space
page.description:
The *actual source map* shows the portion of the source map that is relevant to the provision of a service after accounting for sinks and flow dynamics. For provisioning services, this is the amount and location of a benefit that actually provides benefits to the users. For preventive services, it shows where the actual damage came from. Source regions that provided a damaging carrier were neutralized by sinks are not shown.
This map shows open space providing proximity when accounting for flow paths, sinks, and the location of beneficiaries.
page.see-also: The aesthetic views and proximity section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Blocking proximity sink
page.title: Blocking proximity sink
page.description:
The *actual sink map* shows the portion of the sinks that actually contribute to depleting a service carrier given its flow patterns. For provisioning services, such sinks are responsible for reducing the benefits compared to their possible value. For preventive services, such sinks provide the actual service because they prevent a damaging carrier from reaching users.
This map shows highways that actually separate residences from open space.
page.see-also: The aesthetic views and proximity section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Homeowners with proximate open space
page.title: Homeowners with proximate open space
page.description:
The *actual use map* shows the level of use of a beneficial carrier for a provisioning service or damage caused by a detrimental carrier for a preventive service, for users located across the landscape.
This map shows homeowners benefiting from proximity after accounting for sources of open space, sinks, and flow paths.
page.see-also: The aesthetic views and proximity section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Homeowners without proximate open space
page.title: Homeowners without proximate open space
page.description:
The *inaccessible use map* shows the potential users that cannot receive a service carrier due to flow routes and the source and user locations. For provisioning services, this corresponds to value produced by the environment but that cannot be reached by users. For preventive services, it corresponds to damage that could have been inflicted on users but is not due to a lack of flow connections to users.
This map shows homeowners lacking any proximity to open space due to their location (typically in urban areas).
page.see-also: The aesthetic views and proximity section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Blocked proximity
page.title: Blocked proximity
page.description:
The *blocked flow map* shows the flow paths that could have delivered the service carrier to humans based on the flow routes and the source and user locations, but did not because of the action of sinks. These are selected from among all actual flows.
For provisioning services, these flow paths show the loss in possible flow of beneficial services to the users, and their density is proportional to the value lost. For preventive services, the flow paths show the amount of the total flow that was prevented by natural features from causing damage.
This map shows flows of open space proximity toward homeowners that are blocked by highways.
page.see-also: The aesthetic views and proximity section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Homeowners with blocked proximity
page.title: Homeowners with blocked proximity
page.description:
The *blocked use map* shows those users that would have been reached by the service carrier based only on the source and the flow dynamics, but were not reached because of the action of sinks. For provisioning services, the map shows possible value that has not been accrued to users because of sinks; for preventive services, it shows actual value accrued by users thanks to sink configuration.
For preventive services, therefore, this map is the ultimate quantification of value given the locations and quantity of users and natural sink features.
This map shows homeowners who would receive benefits from open space proximity but have their access blocked by highways.
